text: All sovereign power belongs to the people of Kenya and shall be exercised only in accordance with this Constitution. The people may exercise their sovereign power directly or through their democratically elected representatives. Sovereign power is delegated to Parliament, the legislative assemblies in the county governments, the national executive, and the executive structures in the county governments, and the Judiciary and independent tribunals. The sovereign power of the people is exercised at the national and county levels.

This Constitution is the supreme law of the Republic and binds all persons and all State organs at both levels of government. No person may claim or exercise State authority except as authorized under this Constitution. The validity or legality of this Constitution is not subject to challenge by or before any court or other State organ. Any law, including customary law, that is inconsistent with this Constitution is void to the extent of the inconsistency, and any act or omission in contravention of this Constitution is invalid. This Constitution shall bind all persons and all State organs at both levels of government. The general rules of international law shall form part of the law of Kenya. Any treaty or convention ratified by Kenya shall form part of the law of Kenya under this Constitution.
Every person has an obligation to respect, uphold and defend this Constitution. Any attempt to establish a government otherwise than in compliance with this Constitution is unlawful.
Kenya is a sovereign Republic. Kenya shall be a multi-party democratic State founded on the national values and principles of governance referred to in Article 10.
Kenya comprises the territory and territorial waters comprising Kenya on the effective date, and any additional territory and territorial waters as defined by an Act of Parliament.

The territory of Kenya is divided into counties. The governments at the national and county levels are distinct and inter-dependent and shall conduct their mutual relations on the basis of consultation and cooperation.

The national language of the Republic is Kiswahili. The official languages of the Republic are Kiswahili and English. The State shall promote and protect the diversity of language of the people of Kenya and promote the development and use of indigenous languages, Kenyan Sign Language, Braille and other communication formats and technologies accessible to persons with disabilities.
There shall be no State religion. The State shall not establish any religion, state preference for any religion, or require any person to participate in any religious activity.

A national symbol of the Republic is the national flag, the national anthem, the coat of arms and the public seal. Other national symbols may be prescribed by legislation. The national symbols are recognised by this Constitution and shall be respected by all citizens.

The national values and principles of governance include patriotism, national unity, sharing and devolution of power, the rule of law, democracy and participation of the people; human dignity, equity, social justice, inclusiveness, equality, human rights, non-discrimination and protection of the marginalized; good governance, integrity, transparency and accountability; and sustainable development. These values bind all State organs, State officers, public officers and all persons whenever they apply or interpret this Constitution, enact, apply or interpret any law, or make or implement public policy decisions.

This Constitution recognises culture as the foundation of the nation and as the cumulative civilization of the Kenyan people and nation. The State shall promote all forms of national and cultural expression through literature, the arts, traditional celebrations, science, communication, information, mass media, publications, libraries and other cultural heritage. The State shall promote the intellectual property rights of the people of Kenya. Parliament shall enact legislation to recognise and protect the ownership of indigenous seeds and plant varieties, their genetic and diverse characteristics and their use by the communities of Kenya.

Every citizen is entitled to the rights, privileges and benefits of citizenship subject to the limits provided or permitted by this Constitution. A passport or other document of registration or identification issued by the State to a citizen shall not be withheld or denied arbitrarily.

Citizenship is not lost through marriage or the dissolution of marriage. Citizenship may be acquired by birth or registration. A person is a citizen by birth if either parent is a citizen of Kenya. A child found in Kenya who appears to be less than eight years of age, and whose nationality and parents are not known, is presumed to be a citizen by birth.

A person is a citizen by registration if, having been lawfully resident in Kenya for a continuous period of at least seven years, they apply to the Cabinet Secretary responsible for citizenship matters. Citizenship may also be acquired by marriage to a citizen, or by adoption.

Parliament shall enact legislation providing for the acquisition of citizenship by persons who are married to citizens of Kenya; by persons who have been lawfully resident in Kenya for at least seven years; and by children who are adopted by citizens of Kenya.
A citizen by birth does not lose citizenship by acquiring the citizenship of another country. Kenya allows dual citizenship.

If a person acquired citizenship by registration, the citizenship may be revoked if the person acquired it by fraud, false representation, or concealment of material fact; has, during any war in which Kenya was engaged, unlawfully traded or communicated with an enemy or been engaged in business that was carried on in such manner as to assist an enemy; or has within five years after registration been convicted of an offence and sentenced to imprisonment for a term of three years or longer.
Parliament shall enact legislation establishing conditions for the granting of citizenship.

The Bill of Rights is an integral part of Kenyaâ€™s democratic state and is the framework for social, economic and cultural policies. The purpose of recognising and protecting human rights and fundamental freedoms is to preserve the dignity of individuals and communities and to promote social justice and the realisation of the potential of all human beings.

The Bill of Rights applies to all law and binds all State organs and all persons. Every person shall enjoy the rights and fundamental freedoms in the Bill of Rights to the greatest extent consistent with the nature of the right or fundamental freedom. In applying a provision of the Bill of Rights, a court shall develop the law to the extent that it does not give effect to a right or fundamental freedom, and may adopt the interpretation that most favours the enforcement of a right or fundamental freedom.

It is a fundamental duty of the State and every State organ to observe, respect, protect, promote and fulfil the rights and fundamental freedoms in the Bill of Rights. The State shall take legislative, policy and other measures, including the setting of standards, to achieve the progressive realisation of the rights guaranteed under Article 43. All State organs and all public officers have the duty to address the needs of vulnerable groups within society, including women, older members of society, persons with disabilities, children, youth, members of minority or marginalised communities, and members of particular ethnic, religious or cultural communities.

Every person has the right to institute court proceedings claiming that a right or fundamental freedom in the Bill of Rights has been denied, violated or infringed, or is threatened. In addition to a person acting in their own interest, court proceedings may be instituted by a person acting on behalf of another person who cannot act in their own name; a person acting as a member of, or in the interest of, a group or class of persons; a person acting in the public interest; or an association acting in the interest of one or more of its members.

The High Court has jurisdiction, in accordance with Article 165, to hear and determine applications for redress of a denial, violation or infringement of, or threat to, a right or fundamental freedom in the Bill of Rights. In any proceedings brought under Article 22, a court may grant appropriate relief, including a declaration of rights; an injunction; a conservatory order; a declaration of invalidity of any law that denies, violates, infringes, or threatens a right or fundamental freedom; an order for compensation; and an order of judicial review.

A right or fundamental freedom in the Bill of Rights shall not be limited except by law, and then only to the extent that the limitation is reasonable and justifiable in an open and democratic society based on human dignity, equality and freedom. In determining whether the limitation is reasonable and justifiable, all relevant factors shall be taken into account, including the nature of the right; the importance of the purpose of the limitation; the nature and extent of the limitation; the need to ensure that the enjoyment of rights and fundamental freedoms by any individual does not prejudice the rights and fundamental freedoms of others; and the relation between the limitation and its purpose and whether there are less restrictive means to achieve the purpose.

Despite any other provision in this Constitution, the following rights and fundamental freedoms shall not be limited: freedom from torture and cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment; freedom from slavery or servitude; the right to a fair trial; and the right to an order of habeas corpus.

Every person has the right to life. A person shall not be deprived of life intentionally, except to the extent authorised by this Constitution or other written law. The life of a person begins at conception. Abortion is not permitted unless, in the opinion of a trained health professional, there is need for emergency treatment, or the life or health of the mother is in danger, or if permitted by any other written law.

Every person is equal before the law and has the right to equal protection and equal benefit of the law. Equality includes the full and equal enjoyment of all rights and fundamental freedoms. The State shall not discriminate directly or indirectly against any person on any ground, including race, sex, pregnancy, marital status, health status, ethnic or social origin, colour, age, disability, religion, conscience, belief, culture, dress, language or birth.
Every person has inherent dignity and the right to have that dignity respected and protected.

Every person has the right to freedom and security of the person, which includes the right not to be deprived of freedom arbitrarily or without just cause; detained without trial, except during a state of emergency; subjected to any form of violence from either public or private sources; subjected to torture in any manner, whether physical or psychological; subjected to corporal punishment; or treated or punished in a cruel, inhuman or degrading manner.
Every person has the right not to be held in slavery or servitude, and not to be required to perform forced labour.

Every person has the right to privacy, which includes the right not to have their person, home or property searched; their possessions seized; information relating to their family or private affairs unnecessarily required or revealed; or the privacy of their communications infringed.

Every person has the right to freedom of conscience, religion, thought, belief and opinion. Every person has the right, either individually or in community with others, in public or in private, to manifest any religion or belief through worship, practice, teaching or observance, including observance of a day of worship. A person may not be compelled to act, or engage in any act, that is contrary to the personâ€™s belief or religion.

Every person has the right to freedom of expression, which includes freedom to seek, receive or impart information or ideas; freedom of artistic creativity; and academic freedom and freedom of scientific research. The right to freedom of expression does not extend to propaganda for war; incitement to violence; hate speech; or advocacy of hatred that constitutes ethnic incitement, vilification of others or incitement to cause harm. In the exercise of the right to freedom of expression, every person shall respect the rights and reputation of others.

Freedom and independence of electronic, print and all other types of media is guaranteed, but does not extend to any expression specified in Article 33(2). The State shall not exercise control over or interfere with any person engaged in broadcasting, the production or circulation of any publication, or the dissemination of information by any medium; or penalise any person for any opinion or view or the content of any broadcast, publication or dissemination. Broadcasting and other electronic media have freedom of establishment, subject only to licensing procedures that are necessary to regulate the airwaves and other forms of signal distribution, and that are independent of control by government, political interests or commercial interests.

Every citizen has the right of access to information held by the State; and information held by another person and required for the exercise or protection of any right or fundamental freedom. Every person has the right to the correction or deletion of untrue or misleading information that affects the person. The State shall publish and publicise any important information affecting the nation.

Every person has the right to freedom of association, which includes the right to form, join or participate in the activities of an association of any kind. A person shall not be compelled to join an association of any kind. Any legislation that requires registration of an association of any kind shall provide that registration may not be withheld or withdrawn unreasonably.
Every person has the right, peaceably and unarmed, to assemble, to demonstrate, to picket, and to present petitions to public authorities.

Every citizen is free to make political choices, which includes the right to form, or participate in forming, a political party; to participate in the activities of, or recruit members for, a political party; or to campaign for a political party or cause. Every citizen has the right to free, fair and regular elections based on universal suffrage and the free expression of the will of the electors.
Every person has the right to freedom of movement. Every person has the right to leave Kenya. Every citizen has the right to enter, remain in and reside anywhere in Kenya.

Subject to Article 65, every person has the right, either individually or in association with others, to acquire and own property of any description and in any part of Kenya. Parliament shall not enact a law that permits the State or any person to arbitrarily deprive a person of property of any description, or of any interest in, or right over, any property of any description. The State shall support, promote and protect the intellectual property rights of the people of Kenya.

Every person has the right to fair labour practices. Every worker has the right to fair remuneration; to reasonable working conditions; to form, join or participate in the activities and programmes of a trade union; and to go on strike. Every employer has the right to form and join an employersâ€™ organisation and to participate in its activities. Every trade union and every employersâ€™ organisation has the right to determine its own administration, programmes and activities; to organise; and to form and join a federation. Every trade union, employersâ€™ organisation and employer has the right to engage in collective bargaining.

Every person has the right to a clean and healthy environment, which includes the right to have the environment protected for the benefit of present and future generations through legislative and other measures; and to have obligations relating to the environment fulfilled under Article 70.

Every person has the right to the highest attainable standard of health, which includes the right to health care services, including reproductive health care. Every person has the right to accessible and adequate housing, and to reasonable standards of sanitation. Every person has the right to be free from hunger, and to have adequate food of acceptable quality. Every person has the right to clean and safe water in adequate quantities. Every person has the right to social security. Every person has the right to education.

Every person has the right to use the language, and to participate in the cultural life, of the personâ€™s choice. A person belonging to a cultural or linguistic community has the right, with other members of that community, to enjoy the personâ€™s culture and use the personâ€™s language; or to form, join and maintain cultural and linguistic associations and other organs of civil society. A person shall not compel another person to perform, observe or undergo any cultural practice or rite.

The family is the natural and fundamental unit of society and the necessary basis of social order, and shall enjoy the recognition and protection of the State. Every adult has the right to marry a person of the opposite sex, based on the free consent of the parties. Parties to a marriage are entitled to equal rights at the time of the marriage, during the marriage and at the dissolution of the marriage.

Consumers have the right to goods and services of reasonable quality; to the information necessary for them to gain full benefit from goods and services; to the protection of their health, safety, and economic interests; and to compensation for loss or injury arising from defects in goods or services. Parliament shall enact legislation to provide for consumer protection and for fair, honest and decent advertising.

Every person has the right to administrative action that is expeditious, efficient, lawful, reasonable and procedurally fair. If a right or fundamental freedom of a person has been or is likely to be adversely affected by administrative action, the person has the right to be given written reasons for the action.
The State shall ensure access to justice for all persons and, if any fee is required, it shall be reasonable and shall not impede access to justice.

An arrested person has the right to be informed promptly, in language that the person understands, of the reason for the arrest; to remain silent; to communicate with an advocate, and other persons whose assistance is necessary; not to be compelled to make any confession or admission that could be used in evidence against the person; to be held separately from persons serving a sentence; to be brought before a court as soon as reasonably possible, but not later than twenty-four hours after being arrested; to be released on bond or bail, on reasonable conditions, pending a charge or trial, unless there are compelling reasons not to be released; and to a fair trial.

Every person has the right to have any dispute that can be resolved by the application of law decided in a fair and public hearing before a court or, if appropriate, another independent and impartial tribunal or body. Every accused person has the right to a fair trial, which includes the right to be presumed innocent until the contrary is proved; to be informed of the charge, with sufficient detail to answer it; to have adequate time and facilities to prepare a defence; to a public trial before a court established under this Constitution; to have the trial begin and conclude without unreasonable delay; to be present when being tried, unless the conduct of the accused person makes it impossible for the trial to proceed; to choose, and be represented by, an advocate; and to be given adequate time and facilities to prepare a defence.

A person who is detained, held in custody or imprisoned under the law, retains all the rights and fundamental freedoms in the Bill of Rights, except to the extent that any particular right or fundamental freedom is clearly incompatible with the fact that the person is detained, held in custody or imprisoned. A person shall not be denied the rights to petition for an order of habeas corpus.
The State shall take legislative, policy and other measures to achieve the progressive realisation of the rights guaranteed under Article 43.

Every child has the right to a name and nationality from birth; to free and compulsory basic education; to basic nutrition, shelter and health care; to be protected from abuse, neglect, harmful cultural practices, all forms of violence, inhuman treatment and punishment, and hazardous or exploitative labour; and to parental care and protection. A childâ€™s best interests are of paramount importance in every matter concerning the child.

A person with any disability is entitled to be treated with dignity and respect and to be addressed and referred to in a manner that is not demeaning; to access educational institutions and facilities for persons with disabilities that are integrated into society to the extent compatible with the interests of the person; to reasonable access to all places, public transport and information; to use Sign language, Braille or other appropriate means of communication; and to access materials and devices to overcome constraints arising from the personâ€™s disability.

The State shall take measures, including affirmative action programmes, to ensure that the youth access relevant education and training; have opportunities to associate, be represented and participate in political, social, economic and other spheres of life; access employment; and are protected from harmful cultural practices and exploitation.

The State shall put in place affirmative action programmes designed to ensure that minorities and marginalised groups participate and are represented in governance and other spheres of life; are provided special opportunities in educational and economic fields; are provided special opportunities for access to employment; develop their cultural values, languages and practices; and have reasonable access to water, health services and infrastructure.

The State shall take measures to ensure the rights of older persons to fully participate in the affairs of society; to pursue their personal development; to live in dignity and respect and be free from abuse; and to receive reasonable care and assistance from their family and the State.

A state of emergency may be declared only when the State is threatened by war, invasion, general insurrection, disorder, natural disaster or other public emergency; and the declaration is necessary to meet the circumstances for which the emergency is declared. A declaration of a state of emergency, and any legislation enacted or other action taken in consequence of it, shall be effective only prospectively, and shall not be effective for more than fourteen days from the date of the declaration, unless approved by the National Assembly.

The Kenya National Human Rights and Equality Commission is established. It shall promote respect for human rights and develop a culture of human rights in the Republic; promote gender equality and equity generally; and coordinate and facilitate the mainstreaming of issues of women, persons with disabilities and other marginalised groups.

Land in Kenya shall be held, used and managed in a manner that is equitable, efficient, productive and sustainable, and in accordance with the principles of equitable access to land; security of land rights; sustainable and productive management of land resources; transparent and cost effective administration of land; sound conservation and protection of ecologically sensitive areas; elimination of gender discrimination in law, customs and practices related to land and property in land; and encouragement of communities to settle land disputes through recognised local community initiatives.
All land in Kenya belongs to the people of Kenya collectively as a nation, as communities and as individuals. Land is classified as public, community or private.

Public land is land vested in and held by the national government in trust for the people of Kenya and shall be administered by the National Land Commission. This includes land that is lawfully held, used or occupied by any State organ (except where the State organ is a lessee under a private lease); land transferred to the State by way of sale, reversion or surrender; land in respect of which no individual or community ownership can be established; all minerals and mineral oils; government forests, game reserves, water catchment areas, national parks, government animal sanctuaries and specially protected areas; and all roads, thoroughfares and other lands used for public purposes.

Community land shall vest in and be held by communities identified on the basis of ethnicity, culture or similar community of interest. Community land consists of land lawfully registered in the name of group representatives; land lawfully transferred to a specific community; any other land declared to be community land by an Act of Parliament; and land that is lawfully held, managed or used by specific communities as community forests, grazing areas or shrines.
Private land consists of registered land held by any person under freehold tenure; land held by any person under leasehold tenure; and any other land declared private land under an Act of Parliament.
A person who is not a citizen may hold land on the basis of leasehold tenure only, and any such lease, however granted, shall not exceed ninety-nine years.
The State may regulate the use of any land, or any interest in or right over any land, in the interest of defence, public safety, public order, public morality, public health, or land use planning.

The National Land Commission is established. Its functions are to manage public land on behalf of the national and county governments; recommend a national land policy to the national government; advise the national government on a comprehensive programme for the registration of title in land throughout Kenya; conduct research related to land and the use of natural resources, and make recommendations to appropriate authorities; initiate investigations into present or historical land injustices and recommend appropriate redress; and encourage the application of traditional dispute resolution mechanisms in land conflicts.

Parliament shall enact legislation to prescribe minimum and maximum land holding acreages; to regulate the recognition and protection of matrimonial property and matrimonial homes; to regulate the conversion of land from one category to another; to provide for community land; and to provide for any other matter necessary to give effect to the principles of land in this Constitution.

The State shall ensure sustainable exploitation, utilisation, management and conservation of the environment and natural resources, and ensure the equitable sharing of the accruing benefits. The State shall work to achieve and maintain a tree cover of at least ten percent of the land area of Kenya; protect and enhance intellectual property in, and indigenous knowledge of, biodiversity and the genetic resources of the communities; and establish systems of environmental impact assessment, environmental audit and monitoring of the environment.

If a person alleges that a right to a clean and healthy environment recognised and protected under Article 42 has been, is being or is likely to be denied, violated, infringed or threatened, the person may apply to a court for redress in addition to any other legal remedies that are available in respect to the same matter.

A transaction that involves the grant of a right or concession by or on behalf of any person, including the State, to another person for the exploitation of any natural resource of Kenya is subject to ratification by Parliament.
Parliament shall enact legislation to give full effect to the provisions of this Part.

Authority assigned to a State officer is a public trust to be exercised in a manner that is consistent with the purposes and objects of the Constitution, demonstrates respect for the people, brings honour to the nation and dignity to the office, and promotes public confidence in the integrity of the office.

Before assuming a State office, acting in a State office, or performing any functions of a State office, a person shall take and subscribe the oath or affirmation of office, in the manner and form prescribed by the Third Schedule or under an Act of Parliament.

A State officer shall behave, whether in public and official life, in private life, or in association with other persons, in a manner that avoids any conflict between personal interests and public or official duties; compromises any public or official interest in favour of a personal interest; or demeans the office the officer holds.
A gift or donation to a State officer on a public or official occasion is a gift or donation to the Republic and shall be delivered to the State unless exempted under an Act of Parliament.

A full-time State officer shall not participate in any other gainful employment. Any appointed State officer shall not hold office in a political party. A retired State officer may not hold more than two concurrent remunerative positions as chairperson, director or employee of a company owned or controlled by the State.
A person is not eligible for election or appointment to a State office unless the person is a citizen of Kenya. A State officer or a member of the defence forces shall not hold dual citizenship.

Parliament shall enact legislation to establish an independent ethics and anti-corruption commission, which shall be responsible for ensuring compliance with, and enforcement of, the provisions on leadership and integrity.
Parliament shall enact legislation to establish procedures and mechanisms for the effective administration of this Chapter.

The electoral system shall comply with the following principles: freedom of citizens to exercise their political rights; not more than two-thirds of the members of elective public bodies shall be of the same gender; fair representation of persons with disabilities; universal suffrage based on the aspiration for fair representation and equality of the vote; free and fair elections, which are by secret ballot; free from violence, intimidation, improper influence or corruption; conducted by an independent body; transparent; and administered in an impartial, neutral, efficient, accurate and accountable manner.

Parliament shall enact legislation to provide for the conduct of elections and referenda and for the regulation and efficient supervision of elections by the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission.

A person qualifies for registration as a voter at elections or referenda if the person is an adult citizen, is not declared to be of unsound mind, and has not been convicted of an election offence during the preceding five years.
In every election, all candidates and all political parties shall comply with the code of conduct prescribed by the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission.
Any person is eligible to stand as an independent candidate for election if the person is registered as a voter and satisfies the prescribed educational, moral and ethical requirements.

At every election, the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission shall ensure that whatever voting method is used, the system is simple, accurate, verifiable, secure, accountable and transparent.
Parliament shall enact legislation to establish mechanisms for timely settling of electoral disputes.

The Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission is responsible for conducting or supervising referenda and elections to any elective body or office established by this Constitution and any other elections as prescribed by an Act of Parliament.

There shall be 290 constituencies for the purposes of the election of the members of the National Assembly. The Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission shall review the names and boundaries of constituencies at intervals of not less than eight years and not more than twelve years.
Elections for the seats in Parliament provided for under Articles 97(1)(c) and 98(1)(b), (c) and (d) shall be on the basis of proportional representation by use of party lists.

Every political party shall have a national character; must have a democratically elected governing body; promote and uphold national unity; abide by the democratic principles of good governance, promote and practice democracy through regular, fair and free elections; respect the rights of all persons to participate in the political process; respect and promote human rights and fundamental freedoms; and abide by the code of conduct prescribed by Parliament.
Parliament shall enact legislation to provide for the registration of political parties and for their regulation.
There is established a Parliament of Kenya, which shall consist of the National Assembly and the Senate.
The legislative authority of the Republic is derived from the people and, at the national level, is vested in and exercised by Parliament.

The National Assembly represents the people of the constituencies and special interests in the National Assembly; deliberates on and resolves issues of concern to the people; enacts legislation in accordance with this Constitution; determines the allocation of national revenue between the levels of government; and exercises oversight over national revenue and expenditure.

The Senate represents the counties, and serves to protect the interests of the counties and their governments. The Senate participates in the law-making function of Parliament by considering, debating and approving Bills concerning counties.

The National Assembly consists of two hundred and ninety members, each elected by the registered voters of single member constituencies; forty-seven women, each elected by the registered voters of the counties; twelve members nominated by parliamentary political parties according to their proportion of members of the National Assembly; and the Speaker, who is an ex officio member.

The Senate consists of forty-seven members each elected by the registered voters of the counties; sixteen women members nominated by political parties according to their proportion of members of the Senate; two members, being one man and one woman, representing the youth; two members, being one man and one woman, representing persons with disabilities; and the Speaker, who is an ex officio member.

Unless disqualified under clause (2), a person is eligible for election as a member of Parliament if the person is registered as a voter; satisfies any educational, moral and ethical requirements prescribed by this Constitution or an Act of Parliament; and is nominated by a political party, or is an independent candidate.
Parliament shall enact legislation to promote the representation in Parliament of women; persons with disabilities; youth; ethnic and other minorities; and marginalised communities.
A general election of members of Parliament shall be held on the second Tuesday in August in every fifth year.
The term of each House of Parliament expires on the date of the next general election.

The office of a member of Parliament becomes vacant if the member dies, resigns, is absent from eight sittings without permission, is expelled by their party, or is otherwise disqualified under this Constitution.
The electorate under Articles 97 and 98 have the right to recall the member of Parliament representing their constituency before the end of the term of the relevant House of Parliament.
The High Court shall hear and determine any question whether a person has been validly elected as a member of Parliament or whether the seat has become vacant.
Each House of Parliament shall have a Speaker elected by that House and may elect a Deputy Speaker from among its members.
The Speaker of the National Assembly shall preside at any sitting of that House. The Speaker of the Senate shall preside at any sitting of that House.
There shall be a Leader of the Majority Party and a Leader of the Minority Party in the National Assembly.
Parliament shall exercise its legislative power through Bills passed by Parliament and assented to by the President.

A Bill concerning county governments is a Bill that contains provisions affecting the functions and powers of the county governments or relating to the election of members of a county assembly or a county executive.
A Bill concerning counties may be introduced in the Senate. If passed by the Senate, it shall be considered by the National Assembly.
If one House passes an ordinary Bill concerning counties, and the other House rejects it, the Bill shall be referred to a mediation committee.
If a mediation committee fails to agree within thirty days, the Bill is defeated.
A money Bill may be introduced only in the National Assembly, in accordance with the recommendation of the Budget Committee.
The President shall, within fourteen days after receiving a Bill, either assent to it or refer it back to Parliament for reconsideration.
A Bill passed by Parliament and assented to by the President becomes law upon its publication in the Gazette.
There shall be freedom of speech and debate in Parliament.
Parliament shall conduct its business in an open manner, and its sittings and those of its committees shall be open to the public.
Every person has a right to petition Parliament to consider any matter within its authority, including to enact, amend or repeal any legislation.
The official languages of Parliament are Kiswahili, English and Kenyan Sign Language, and business may be conducted in any of them.
Parliament shall sit at such times and for such periods as it may determine.
Except as otherwise provided, any question proposed for decision in either House of Parliament shall be determined by a majority of the members present and voting.
On a question before the Senate, each county delegation shall have one vote.
Each House of Parliament may establish committees and make Standing Orders for the orderly conduct of its business.
Either House of Parliament, and any of its committees, has power to summon any person to appear before it for the purpose of giving evidence or providing information.
A sitting of either House may be held at any place within Kenya, and Parliament shall sit in public but may exclude persons in exceptional circumstances.
There is established a Parliamentary Service Commission, which shall provide services and facilities to ensure the efficient and effective functioning of Parliament.
The Clerk of the Senate and the Clerk of the National Assembly are responsible for the day-to-day running of the respective Houses.
Executive authority derives from the people of Kenya and shall be exercised in accordance with this Constitution.
The national executive comprises the President, the Deputy President and the rest of the Cabinet.
The President is the Head of State and Government, Commander-in-Chief of the Defence Forces, and a symbol of national unity.
The President shall address Parliament annually on measures taken and progress achieved in realising national values, submit a report for debate, and nominate key state officers.
The President may exercise the power of mercy, in accordance with the advice of the Advisory Committee.
When the President is absent or incapacitated, the Deputy President shall act as President.
A decision of the President in the performance of any function shall be in writing and signed.
The President shall be elected by registered voters in a national election.

A person is qualified for nomination as a presidential candidate if the person is a citizen by birth, qualified to stand for election as a member of Parliament, and is nominated by a political party or is an independent candidate.
The election of the President shall be by secret ballot and shall be conducted by the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission.
If a President-elect dies before being sworn in, a fresh election shall be held within sixty days.
A person may file a petition in the Supreme Court to challenge the election of the President-elect within seven days.
The President-elect shall be sworn in on the first Tuesday following the fourteenth day after the Supreme Court renders a decision on the presidential election petition.
The President shall hold office for a term beginning on the date of swearing-in and ending when the next President is sworn in.
The President shall not be held liable in civil or criminal proceedings during the tenure of office.
The President shall cease to hold office if declared incapacitated by a resolution supported by a two-thirds majority of all members of Parliament.
The President may be impeached on grounds of gross violation of the Constitution, or other serious reasons.
The office of President becomes vacant if the holder of the office dies, resigns, or is removed from office under this Constitution.
The Deputy President is the principal assistant of the President and deputises in the execution of functions.
Each candidate for election as President shall nominate a person qualified for nomination for election as Deputy President.
If a vacancy occurs in the office of Deputy President, the President shall nominate a person to fill the vacancy, with approval of the National Assembly.
The Deputy President may be removed from office on the ground of physical or mental incapacity, or gross misconduct.

title: Secretary to the Cabinet
text: The President nominates and, with the approval of the National Assembly, appoints the Secretary to the Cabinet, who is responsible for arranging Cabinet business and keeping minutes.

title: Cabinet Secretaries
text: Cabinet Secretaries are nominated by the President, approved by the National Assembly, and responsible for running ministries.

title: Decisions, Responsibility and Accountability of the Cabinet
text: Decisions of the Cabinet are collective, and members are accountable to the President and Parliament.

title: Secretary to the Cabinet
text: The Secretary to the Cabinet keeps minutes and communicates Cabinet decisions.

title: Principal Secretaries
text: The President appoints Principal Secretaries to oversee State departments.

title: Attorney-General
text: The Attorney-General is the principal legal adviser to the government and represents the State in legal matters.

title: Director of Public Prosecutions
text: The DPP has power to prosecute criminal cases independently, without direction or control.

title: Removal of Director of Public Prosecutions
text: The DPP may be removed on grounds of incapacity, gross misconduct, or incompetence.

title: Judicial Authority
text: Judicial authority is derived from the people and exercised by courts in accordance with the Constitution.

title: Independence of the Judiciary
text: The Judiciary is independent and not subject to control by any person or authority.

title: Judicial Officers and Staff
text: Judicial officers and staff are appointed and serve in accordance with judicial service regulations.

title: System of Courts
text: The superior courts consist of the Supreme Court, Court of Appeal, High Court, and specialized courts.

title: Supreme Court
text: The Supreme Court is the highest court in Kenya, consisting of the Chief Justice, Deputy Chief Justice, and judges.

title: Court of Appeal
text: The Court of Appeal hears appeals from the High Court and other lower courts as prescribed by law.

title: High Court
text: The High Court has unlimited jurisdiction in criminal and civil matters, including constitutional interpretation.

title: Appointment of Judges
text: Judges are appointed by the President on the recommendation of the Judicial Service Commission and approval by the National Assembly.

title: Tenure of Judges
text: Judges retire at age 70 but may elect to retire earlier at 65.

title: Removal of a Judge
text: A judge may be removed on grounds of incapacity, misconduct, or incompetence following due process.

title: Subordinate Courts
text: The subordinate courts include Magistrates Courts, Kadhisâ€™ Courts, and other courts established by Parliament.

title: Kadhisâ€™ Courts
text: Kadhisâ€™ Courts have jurisdiction over questions of Muslim law relating to personal status, marriage, divorce, or inheritance.

title: Judicial Service Commission
text: The JSC is established to promote and facilitate independence and accountability of the Judiciary.

title: Functions of the Judicial Service Commission
text: The JSC recommends judicial appointments, reviews conditions of service, and ensures efficiency in the Judiciary.

title: Judiciary Fund
text: A Judiciary Fund is established to ensure financial independence of the Judiciary.

title: Objects of Devolution
text: Devolution promotes democratic and accountable exercise of power, national unity, and self-governance of the people.

title: Principles of Devolved Government
text: County governments are based on democratic principles, separation of powers, and reliable sources of revenue.

title: County Governments
text: A county government consists of a county assembly and a county executive.

title: Membership of County Assembly
text: County Assemblies consist of elected members, special seats for gender balance, marginalized groups, and party lists.

title: Speaker of County Assembly
text: Each County Assembly elects a Speaker from outside the Assembly members.

title: County Executive Committees
text: The County Executive consists of the Governor, Deputy Governor, and County Executive Committee Members.

title: Election of County Governor and Deputy Governor
text: Governors are elected by county voters, and the Governor nominates a Deputy Governor as a running mate.

title: Removal of a County Governor
text: A Governor may be removed for gross violation of the Constitution, crime, or abuse of office.

title: Vacancy in the Office of County Governor
text: A vacancy arises in the office of Governor due to death, resignation, impeachment, or incapacity.

title: Functions of County Executive Committees
text: CEC members implement county legislation and manage county administration.

title: Urban Areas and Cities
text: Parliament enacts legislation to govern classification, governance, and management of urban areas and cities.

title: Legislative Authority of County Assemblies
text: County Assemblies exercise legislative authority at the county level.

title: Respective Functions of National and County Governments
text: The Constitution assigns functions between the national and county levels.

title: Transfer of Functions and Powers
text: Functions may be transferred between national and county governments by agreement.

title: Boundaries of Counties
text: County boundaries may be altered by independent commission and parliamentary approval.

title: Cooperation Between National and County Governments
text: Governments at both levels must cooperate, assist, and support each other.

title: Support for County Governments
text: Parliament ensures county governments have adequate support to perform their functions.

title: Conflict of Laws
text: If a conflict arises between national and county laws, national law prevails in specific cases.

title: Suspension of County Governments
text: A county government may be suspended in an emergency or if it engages in actions against the Constitution.

title: Qualifications for Election as Member of County Assembly
text: A person is qualified if registered as a voter and meets integrity requirements under the Constitution.

title: Vacation of Office of Member of County Assembly
text: An MCAâ€™s seat becomes vacant under conditions like resignation, absence, or election invalidation.

title: County Assembly Powers to Summon
text: A County Assembly may summon anyone to provide information or evidence.

title: Public Participation and County Assembly Powers
text: County Assemblies must facilitate public participation and openness in their work.

title: County Assembly Gender Balance and Diversity
text: County Assemblies must reflect gender balance and diversity as required by law.

title: County Government During Transition
text: County governments continue to operate even when elections or transitions occur.

title: Publication of County Legislation
text: County legislation must be published in the official Gazette to take effect.

title: Legislation on Chapter Eleven
text: Parliament shall enact legislation to give full effect to the principles of devolution.

title: Principles of Public Finance
text: Public finance shall promote equitable society, transparency, accountability, and fair sharing of resources between national and county governments.

title: Equitable Sharing of National Revenue
text: Revenue raised nationally is shared equitably among the national and county governments.

title: Equitable Share and Other Financial Laws
text: Criteria for equitable share include national interest, county needs, and economic disparities.

title: Equalisation Fund
text: The Fund provides services to marginalized areas to bring them to the level of the rest of the nation.

title: Consultation on Financial Legislation Affecting Counties
text: National financial legislation affecting counties must be discussed with county governments.

title: Consolidated Fund and Other Public Funds
text: All money raised or received by the national government is paid into the Consolidated Fund.

title: Revenue Funds for County Governments
text: County governments must establish a Revenue Fund for money raised or allocated to them.

title: Contingencies Fund
text: A fund is established for emergencies and unforeseen expenditures.

title: Power to Impose Taxes and Charges
text: Only the national government may impose income tax, VAT, customs, and excise duties; counties may impose property and entertainment taxes.

title: Imposition of Tax
text: Taxes may only be imposed as authorized by legislation.

title: Borrowing by National Government
text: Parliament must approve national government borrowing.

title: Borrowing by Counties
text: County governments may borrow only with national government guarantee and Assembly approval.

title: Guarantees by National Government
text: The national government may guarantee loans with Parliament's approval.

title: Public Debt
text: Public debt is a charge on the Consolidated Fund.

title: Commission on Revenue Allocation
text: A commission is established to recommend equitable revenue sharing.

title: Functions of the Commission
text: The commission makes recommendations on revenue sharing and financing of devolved government.

title: Division of Revenue
text: Senate determines revenue sharing between national and county governments.

title: Annual Division and Allocation of Revenue Bills
text: Bills must be enacted annually for revenue division and allocation.

title: Transfer of Equitable Share
text: Counties are entitled to equitable share, transferred without delay.

title: Form, Content and Timing of Budgets
text: National and county budgets must contain revenue estimates, expenditure, and financing plans.

title: Budget Estimates and Appropriation
text: Budget estimates are submitted to the National Assembly and approved.

title: Expenditure Before Appropriation
text: The National Assembly may authorize expenditure in advance of appropriation.

title: Supplementary Appropriation
text: Expenditure not in the budget requires supplementary appropriation.

title: County Appropriation
text: County Assemblies approve county budget expenditure.

title: Financial Control
text: National legislation prescribes financial management and control of public funds.

title: Accounts and Auditing
text: Every government entity must maintain accounts and submit them for auditing.

title: Procurement of Public Goods and Services
text: Procurement must be fair, transparent, competitive, and cost-effective.

title: Controller of Budget
text: The Controller of Budget authorizes withdrawals from public funds.

title: Auditor-General
text: The Auditor-General audits all public accounts, funds, and entities.

title: Salaries and Remuneration Commission
text: The SRC sets and reviews salaries and benefits for State officers.

title: Central Bank of Kenya
text: The Central Bank is responsible for monetary policy, issuing currency, and financial stability.

title: Values and Principles of Public Service
text: Public service is based on high standards of professional ethics, efficiency, inclusiveness, and accountability.

title: Public Service Commission
text: The PSC is established to manage public service and human resource matters.

title: Functions of PSC
text: The PSC appoints, promotes, and disciplines public officers.

title: Staffing of County Governments
text: County governments are responsible for their own staffing.

title: Protection of Public Officers
text: Public officers shall not be victimized or discriminated against for performing their duties lawfully.

title: Teachers Service Commission
text: The TSC registers, employs, and manages teachers in public schools.

title: Principles of National Security
text: National security must be pursued in compliance with law and with respect for human rights.

title: National Security Organs
text: The security organs are the Kenya Defence Forces, National Intelligence Service, and National Police Service.

title: National Security Council
text: The NSC exercises supervisory control over national security organs.

title: Defence Forces
text: The Kenya Defence Forces are responsible for defense and may be deployed internally with approval.

title: National Intelligence Service
text: The NIS is responsible for security intelligence and protecting Kenya from internal and external threats.

title: National Police Service
text: The NPS is a national service consisting of the Kenya Police and Administration Police.

title: Objects of the Police Service
text: The Police must strive for professionalism, prevent corruption, and ensure compliance with human rights.

title: Command of the National Police Service
text: The Inspector-General has independent command over the NPS.

title: National Police Service Commission
text: The Commission recruits, appoints, promotes, and disciplines police officers.

title: Other Police Services
text: Parliament may establish other police services under the NPS.

title: Commissions and Independent Offices
text: The Constitution establishes commissions and independent offices for oversight and accountability.

title: Objects of Commissions and Offices
text: Their objects are to protect sovereignty, ensure democracy, and promote constitutionalism.

title: Composition, Appointment and Terms
text: Commissions consist of chairpersons and members appointed by the President with parliamentary approval.

title: Removal of a Member of a Commission
text: Members may be removed on grounds of misconduct, incapacity, or incompetence.

title: General Functions of Commissions
text: Commissions have powers necessary for their functions, including investigations and recommendations.

title: Incorporation of Commissions
text: Commissions are corporate bodies with perpetual succession.

title: Reporting by Commissions
text: Commissions must submit annual reports to the President and Parliament.

title: Amendment of the Constitution
text: Certain provisions can only be amended by referendum.

title: Amendment by Parliamentary Initiative
text: Parliament may amend the Constitution following prescribed procedures.

title: Amendment by Popular Initiative
text: The public may amend the Constitution through a popular initiative and referendum.

title: Enforcement of the Constitution
text: Every person has the right to institute court proceedings to enforce the Constitution.

title: Construing the Constitution
text: The Constitution must be interpreted in a manner that promotes values and principles of democracy.

title: Interpretation
text: This Article defines terms used in the Constitution.

title: Consequential Legislation
text: Parliament must enact legislation required by the Constitution within prescribed timeframes.

title: Transitional and Consequential Provisions
text: Schedules provide transitional arrangements for implementing the Constitution.

title: Citation of the Constitution
text: This Constitution may be cited as the Constitution of Kenya, 2010.

title: Repeal of Previous Constitution
text: The former Constitution of Kenya is repealed upon commencement of the Constitution of Kenya, 2010.
